item.title: Report E-2023100578
item.description:
Report E-2023100578

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-23T15:12:15+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-19
  • City: EAGAN
  • State: MN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XEN experienced a NA1993 Sulfix 9670 Additive release from a 275-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 10-gallons of product released to a 10’ x 25’ area of the concrete dock floor due to a puncture caused by a pallet of rods. The material was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one. Absorbents were then deployed and worked into the impacted area. All impacted absorbents, the cut up damaged tote, and impacted pallets were collected and containerized into (3) 55-gallon metal drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

All spent absorbents, impacted dirt and damaged jug were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum for transport and disposal.

item.title: Report E-2023100546
item.description:
Report E-2023100546

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-23T15:12:15+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-09
  • City: WILMINGTON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 9, 2023, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN1993 was crushed during transit and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. TLE personnel collected one (1) damaged 5-gallon pail of UN1993 for disposal. Crews then deployed granular absorbent to the impacted trailer floor and worked them in utilizing hand tools. Once collected, TLE personnel utilized a degreasing agent with absorbent wipes to collect any residual product. The undamaged freight was re-secured for normal transport. All UN1993 impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal by R+L.

item.title: Report E-2023100544
item.description:
Report E-2023100544

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-23T15:12:15+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-09
  • City: HOLLISTER
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 9, 2023, one (1) 330-gallon tote of UN3098 was punctured and released approximately 467-gallons of product to the trailer interior, lift gate, and asphalt roadway. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Ancon Services (AS) to remediate the impacted site. AS personnel utilized a vacuum pump to transfer the undamaged product from the damaged tote to a new tote and secured for normal transport. Crews then deployed additional granular absorbent and a neutralizing agent to the impacted trailer floor, lift gate and asphalt roadway and worked them in utilizing hand tools. All UN3098 impacted material, including the damaged tote, was collected and containerized in nine (9) 55-gallon drums and were taken to RLC-SJE to be staged and added to the facility waste stream. AS personnel secured the site and scheduled to return at a later date for pressure washing of impacted asphalt and monitor waste at RLC-SJE. On Oct 11, 2023, AS personnel arrived on-site at RLC-SJE and inspected six (6) 55-gallon drums containing UN3098 impacted material. The waste was still reacting and drums were left unsealed in an open trailer. AS personnel secured the site and scheduled to return at a later date to continue monitoring the waste at RLC-SJE. On Oct 12, 2023, AS personnel arrived on-site at RLC-SJE and inspected six (6) 55-gallon drums containing UN3098 impacted material. There was olfactory evidence that the waste was still reacting and drums were left unsealed in an open trailer. AS personnel secured the site and scheduled to return at a later date to continue monitoring the waste at RLC-SJE. On Oct 13, 2023, AS personnel arrived on-site at RLC-SJE and inspected six (6) 55-gallon drums containing UN3098 impacted material. The reaction had ceased. The impacted trailer was re-inspected and it was confirmed that no further remediation necessary at the direction of RLC personnel. AS personnel secured the site and scheduled to return at a later date to secure the waste at RLC-SJE to be added to the facility waste stream. On Oct 16, 2023, AS personnel arrived on-site at RLC-SJE and inspected six (6) 55-gallon drums containing UN3098 impacted material. The reaction had ceased and drums were secured. RLC personnel took possession of nine (9) 55-gallon drums of waste to be added to the facility waste stream.

item.description:

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-06
  • City: SAN ANGELO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 6, 2023, one (1) 5-gallon drum of UN3098 was damaged during transit and released approximately two and a half (2.5) gallons of product to the trailer floor and pavement beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the impacted site. LSH personnel utilized hand tools, absorbents, and sodium bicarbonate to remediate the UN3098-impacted impacted trailer interior and pavement. LSH personnel solidified and neutralized the damaged pail of product. The damaged pail and all impacted debris were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon poly vented drum for transport and disposal.

item.title: Report E-2023100573
item.description:
Report E-2023100573

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-23T15:12:15+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-24
  • City: DETROIT
  • State: MI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CONSOLIDATED RAIL CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 24, 2023 at 20:37 Transportation personnel in the Conrail Livernois Terminal reported that ,GATX 2013 a loaded tank car of FLUOROSILICIC ACID leaking from top of the tank car upon movement. Additionally, during routine switching operations a Conrail Conductor was splashed with acid from the improperly secured tank car. The Conductor was immediately brought in to remove affected clothing and shower of any impacted skin. No reportable injury was encountered as the Conductors and Terminal Supervisions actions removed all material before any health effects took place. The car was isolated and the shipper/consignee PVS was notified directly via phone. Enviroserve, an approved Conrail Contractor was notified to respond, inspect and secure the tank car. Enviroserve personnel, investigated the leak and found the source of the leak to be from the rupture disk assembly. Upon further inspection it was found that the inspection cap was hanging off the housing and no rupture disk was in place beneath the assembly. Additionally, there was no required surge protection on the rupture disk assembly. Enviroserve placed the appropriate rupture disk and resecured the assembly. The tank car was then held until the proper surge protection device could be placed in the assembly. Conrail and Enviroserve worked with the car owner and Steve Kuz, Alltrantec 519-718-8377 to secure the proper service equipment. On October 4, 2023 the new surge protection device was installed on the tank car and it was released back into transportation. Cause Code: 437 5 x ( 5 + 5 + 0 ) x ( 2+ 2 ) = 200

item.title: Report E-2023100468

  • City: Parkersburg
  • State: WV
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX Transportation
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 09/13/2023, at 0239 hours, personnel in the CSXT Parkersburg Yard discovered OLNX 32004, a residue tank car of Hydrochloric Acid, leaking from the top of the car. The car was isolated and the shipper, National Response Center, and West Virginia DEP were notified. (CHEMTREC Report #2023-0913-00015). Quick Response, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found the fill hole cover closed however gasketing material was displaced and preventing a proper seal resulting in a vapor release of lading. The issue was identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper, Mr. Rob Cline of Tetra Technologies, phone 304-482-7655. Contractor personnel properly installed the gasket and fill port cover without incident thus securing the release. The leak was secured and the car was released for transport. This incident did not require a special switching move. 7.1 is not required. Cause Code: 232 NARRI: 90

  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Before inspecting the hazmat, I put on my hazmat safety gloves and made sure that nothing was leaking. When opening the box for further inspection, one of the glass liters was broken and lost all of the content that was inside, the other 3 glass liters had no damage. I grabbed the broken glass pieces with my gloves and threw them away after I took pictures for the report. Then obtained a large yellow barrel and put a blue hazmat bag inside to place the undamaged products in and placed in the hazmat cage until further instructions are given. DescribePack: This package was improperly handled which led to one of the glass liters breaking and losing all the content that was inside. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: By the time I was inspecting the hazmat the liquid had already dried up but in case of further leakage that went unnoticed I placed a cardboard box underneath the original hazmat box.

  • Description: On 09/19/2023, at 1042 hrs. Personnel in the CSXT Ottawa Yard discovered MTZX330221, a residue tank car of Propane, leaking from the protective housing. The car was isolated and NGL Supply Wholesale LLC, NRC, Illinois EMA, Ottawa Fire Department were notified. CHEMTREC Report #2023091900178. (RMS), a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found the secondary closure not applied and laying on the pressure plate and the A-end liquid line valve open 1/8th of a turn). The issue was identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper (Jamee Spears 501-680-2267). Contractor personnel closed the valve, cleaned the threads of the secondary plug, applied new thread tape and tool tightened it in place. The leak was secured and the car was released for transport. This incident (did not) require a special switching move. No 7.1 is required. Cause Code: 312 NARRI: 5

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was discovered on trailer upside down and actively leaking. Sort Manager called out the leaking package immediately upon discovery and orientated the package upright and stopped further leaking. QA Immediately responded by isolating the package into a HAZMAT Tote with Liner to prevent further spillage onto other packages. Spilt liquid was cleaned up with paper towels, and leaked on packages were removed from trailer to be repacked. No packages that were leaked on were damaged. DescribePack: Inspection found 1 of 4 plastic bottles has its lid shoved in and bent at an odd angle. Found source of leakage to be from under the handle. The seam of the bottle had burst outward which formed a large hole. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Package was immediately turned upright, isolated, and contained into a HAZMAT Tote with Liner to prevent further spillage.

  • Description: The third party performed an illegal u-turn on the Interstate going eastbound when our AmeriGas truck was traveling westbound, causing the AmeriGas bobtail to strike the third-party vehicle on the front driver's side causing the vehicle to be totaled on-site. Both vehicles needed to be towed but when the AmeriGas bobtail was being pulled from the ditch the tow company (Unknown) caused a leak at the bottom of the bobtail tank causing the interstate to be closed for a few hours. First responders contained the leak and the AmeriGas bobtail was towed back to the AmeriGas yard, where it was safely unloaded back to the bulk tank.

The package reportedly became lodged in the gears of the conveyor belt, resulting in extensive damage to the package and the inner contents. The shipment will be set for disposal.

  • Description: On 08/31/2023, at 0619, personnel in the CSXT Cumberland Yard discovered UTLX 755938, a residue tank car of Petroleum Gases, Liquified, leaking from the top of the car. The car was isolated and the shipper, Maryland Department of the Environment, and National Response Center were notified. (CHEMTREC Report #2023-0831-00068). The local fire department responded to the site and observed the A-End liquid valve partially open and secondary closure plug less than tool tight, and actively releasing lading. Specialized Professional Services, Inc., a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and confirmed a partially open liquid valve and less than tool tight secondary closure plug. The issue was identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper, Mr. Jeff Dean of Tri Gas and Oil, phone 410-310-6354. Contractor personnel closed the valve and properly installed the secondary closure plug, thus securing the release. The leak was secured and the car was released for transport. This incident did not require a special switching move. 7.1 is not required. Cause Code: 119 NARRI: 90

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-18
  • City: HOUSTON
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Description: At 1745 on 08/18/23 notification was received that tank car TILX 101860 was leaking product from the top and down the side of the car and onto the ground, the tank car was fully loaded with Sulfuric Acid, our contract Haz-Mat company (Haz-Mat Special Services) was notified and responded to the scene. Once they arrived it was discovered that the liquid load line bolts had not been fastened properly and flanges to not meet equally, HMSS was able to repair by reseating the flanges and re-torquing bolts, while pulling the top plug to the liquid line and re-sealing with proper TPFE tape. HMSS then cleaned the car with a solution of soda ash and water to neutralize car parts and side walls, as well as the ground.

item.title: Report I-2023080075
item.description:
Report I-2023080075

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-12
  • City: HOUSTON
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: PORT TERMINAL RAILROAD ASSOCIATION (INC)
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: At 1735 on 08/12/23 notification was received that tank car RCRX 1288 was leaking product from the top and down both sides, upon inspected the tank car was fully loaded with Hydrochloric Acid, our contract Haz-Mat company (Haz-Mat Special Services) was notified and responded to the scene. Once they arrived it was discovered that the Liquid Line Blind Flange had been left unfastened prior to shipping from the customer facility, HMSS was able to fasten the bolts evenly in a star pattern in order to secure the disc and prevent anymore product from leaking. HMSS then cleaned the car with a solution of caustic soda ash and water to neutralize car parts and side walls, as well as the ground and railroad base. HMSS was back on scene Monday morning 08/14/23 to assist with removing and disposing of contaminated rail, ties, plates, anchors and spikes.

  • Description: According to the information obtained, the following occurred. A TruGreen employee was performing an application of product at a residential location when a hose malfunction occurred resulting in the release of approximately 30 gallons of an insecticide, fungicide, pesticide and miticide solution. The free product impacted concrete and a storm drain at the loss location. Clean Harbors Environmental Service was dispatched to perform the cleanup at the loss location. Telephonic regulatory reports were made to the national Response Center. The Kansas Department of Health and Environment, and the Harvey County LEPC. There were no injuries or exposures reported in connection with the release.

  • Description: Upon arrival of American Airlines Flight 515 at LAX from ORD, it was discovered that U.S. Mail in the cargo compartment was leaking. The smell overcame two Fleet Service Clerks who had to go to the Concentra Clinic complaining of dizziness, shortness of breath and headaches from the smell. Once the Mail was offloaded, a box containing a 1 gallon jug of Triclopyr 4, a herbicide was discovered to have leaked approximately 1 quart of its contents due to the pressure differential between the aircraft at altitude and the plastic jug.

  • Carrier/Reporter: WILBUR-ELLIS COMPANY LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: According to the information obtained, the following occurred. While traveling, driver stopped short, which caused one 265 gallon tote to fall and release approximately 99 gallons of free liquid to the roadside soil. Free product was contained to immediate area and did not migrate or threaten to impact state waters. LoneStar Hazmat Response was dispatched to perform the cleanup. Upon arrival on site, LoneStar Hazmat Response deployed absorbent boom to the affected area, due to rainfall, and secured the area pending return for excavation. Lone Star Hazmat returned the following day, excavated the impacted soil, and restored site to preexisting condition. Approximately 12.93 tons of contaminated soil were recovered and transported to Southwest Landfill of Canyon, Texas for disposal. There were no injuries or exposures reported.

item.description:

  • Incident Date: 2023-06-23
  • City: FONTANA
  • State: CA

  • Carrier/Reporter: Oak Harbor Freight Lines
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Ruben went into the trailer with his forklift and grabbed pro: 34020449 which was directly in front of the tote. As Ruben attempted to reverse out of the trailer, the dockplate slowed him down as the plate was at a declining angle from the dock to the trailer. Ruben then rolled slightly forward and his forks punctured the tote. Package failure was puncture by forklift. Holes were about 6 inches by 2 inches. Ruben then notified Supervisor David Hutchens at 9:24 who then immediately attempted to stop the spill by using the fork lift to flip the tote on its side. David attempted to contain the leakage but realized the overwhelming volume was too much. He then used waddles from spills skits and absorbent in attempt to stop the spill. He then radioed to Mark Gonzales about the situation. Additional waddles and absorbent was placed in the yard. Mark Gonzales then informed Josh Fuentes about the situation. After Josh realized the severity of the spill he made the decision to call out Statewide Environmental to assist with the situation.

  • Description: Bobtail drier was driving on Hwy 512 in the far left lane, there was a dump truck hauling a pump trailer in front of him. Apparently a vehicle in front of the dump truck hit its brakes, the dump truck hit its brakes and our bobtail rear ended the truck truck& its trailer. The Ferrellgas employee was injured and sought medical treatment at Concentra Urgent care where he was treated and released for cuts, bruises to both legs and knees. The bolt on the pump broke and the gas in the lines to the meter released. Our employee was able to shut off the valve to the release.
